sentences: Eugénie-Emilie Juliette Folville (born 5 January 1870, d. 28 October 1946) was a Belgian pianist, violinist, music educator, conductor and composer.
Eugénie-Emilie Juliette Folville was born in Liège, Belgium, and began the study of music with her father who was a lawyer and amateur musician.
She studied violin with Charles Malherbe, Ovide Musin and César Thomson and made her debut in Liège in 1879.
She had a successful career on the concert stage, and in 1897 took a position teaching piano at the Royal Conservatory of Liège.
She lived for several years in London, and during World War II she lived and performed in Bournemouth.
She died in Dourgne on 28 October 1946.
Folville composed for theater, solo instruments, orchestra, chorus, and chamber ensemble.
Aux Champs, Dans la montagne, Rêverie, Fête de village
Chanson du pêcheur, Nuit étoilée, Mer phosphorescente, Flots agités, Adieux à l'océan
3e Suite d'orchestre, op. 17 (1887) : Ballade, La neige, Noël, Carnaval
Violin concerto in G Minor, op. 20 (1888)
Triptyque for violin and orchestra, or piano (ca. 1935)
Berceuse for violin and piano, op.
Berceuse for cello and quartet accompaniment [s.d.]
Poème for cello and piano, or orchestra (ca.1908-1909)
Drame lyrique en deux actes (1891), libretto by Paul Collin.
Creation at the Grand Théâtre de Lille on 3 March 1892.
Légende Norwégienne, cantate pour soli, chœurs et accompagnement d'orchestre (ca. 1889), poem by Paul Collin.
Noce au Village, op. 13 (1886), for solo, choir and orchestra, words by Paul Collin.
Drame lyrique en quatre actes, libretto by Alfred Billet, unfinished.
Fauve BOUGARD, "Le morceau sera signé J. Folville".
Itinéraire d'une femme dans la Belgique musicale.
Master thesis in musicology, Université libre de Bruxelles (Belgium), dir.
Free scores by Eugénie-Emilie Juliette Folville at the International Music Score Library Project (IMSLP)
